image.altText: Skyspan umbrella at Cairns School of Distance Education on left, school building with ramps on right

items.synopsis: Education Queensland has admitted to destroying trees planted in memory of deceased teachers as part of spending blitz at distance education school.

title.children: Queensland’s second largest school builds $700k playground despite nearly all 4,300 students learning from home

image.altText: Gladys Berejiklian and Daryl Maguire

items.synopsis: The New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption hands down its findings into former NSW premier Gladys Berejiklian and former Liberal MP, Daryl Maguire. Follow the key moments live in our blog.

title.children: ICAC delivers serious corrupt conduct findings against Berejiklian, Maguire

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ICAC has broken down its decision not to recommend any criminal charges be laid against Gladys Berejiklian. It explored the merits of whether a charge of misconduct in public office could be pursued. ICAC's report says that would go to the state of mind Ms Berejiklian held in relation to her alleged impartiality, and prosecutors would need to exclude explanations such as whether she acted for electoral advantage or to "advance" her relationship with Daryl Maguire. A major obstacle in any prosecution case would be that the former premier gave her evidence to the ICAC under objection, and therefore would not be admissible in a criminal court. There was also no evidence of a private financial advantage obtained by Ms Berejiklian, the report states. "Ultimately, the Commission is of the view that Ms Berejiklian's conduct, while it constitutes or involves a substantial breach of the ministerial code, is not so serious that it could be demonstrated to merit criminal punishment (the fifth element of the offence of misconduct in public office) and therefore does not reach the very high bar required to make out the offence of misconduct in public office."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why charges against Ms Berejiklian were not recommended

children.content: The ICAC has broken down its decision not to recommend any criminal charges be laid against Gladys Berejiklian.
It explored the merits of whether a charge of misconduct in public office could be pursued.

ICAC's report says that would go to the state of mind Ms Berejiklian held in relation to her alleged impartiality, and prosecutors would need to exclude explanations such as whether she acted for electoral advantage or to "advance" her relationship with Daryl Maguire.
A major obstacle in any prosecution case would be that the former premier gave her evidence to the ICAC under objection, and therefore would not be admissible in a criminal court.
There was also no evidence of a private financial advantage obtained by Ms Berejiklian, the report states.

"Ultimately, the Commission is of the view that Ms Berejiklian's conduct, while it constitutes or involves a substantial breach of the ministerial code, is not so serious that it could be demonstrated to merit criminal punishment (the fifth element of the offence of misconduct in public office) and therefore does not reach the very high bar required to make out the offence of misconduct in public office."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Gladys Berejiklian described her relationship with Daryl Maguire as "intensely private terrain," according to the ICAC report. However, the inquiry found it was of the public interest to investigate the influence this had over her decision-making. Ms Berejiklian submitted that as premier, the ministerial code did not apply to her. The Ministerial Code sets out the standard of conduct expected of ministers and how they discharge their duties. ICAC has rejected Ms Berejiklian's submission, and found she substantially breached the ministerial code by failing in her duty "to act honestly and in the public interest," in her conduct regarding the Riverina Conservatorium of Music grant. The Commission also found Ms Berejiklian engaged in corrupt conduct when promising, or awarding grant money to the Australian Clay Target Association, without disclosing her close personal relationship with Mr Maguire.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Close personal relationship exposed

children.content: Gladys Berejiklian described her relationship with Daryl Maguire as
"intensely private terrain,"
according to the ICAC report.
However, the inquiry found it was of the public interest to investigate the influence this had over her decision-making.
Ms Berejiklian submitted that as premier, the ministerial code
did not apply to her.
The Ministerial Code sets out the standard of conduct expected of ministers and how they discharge their duties.
ICAC
has rejected Ms Berejiklian's submission
, and found she substantially breached the ministerial code by failing in her duty "to act honestly and in the public interest," in her conduct regarding the
Riverina Conservatorium of Music
grant.
The Commission also found Ms Berejiklian engaged in corrupt conduct when promising, or awarding grant money to the
Australian Clay Target Association,
without disclosing her close personal relationship with Mr Maguire.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: While ICAC will not be obtaining advice of the DPP over the possible prosecution of Ms Berejiklian, it will be referring Mr Maguire to the DPP for possible criminal charges over his involvement in an alleged visa scheme involving company G8wayInternational. The ICAC found Mr Maguire improperly used his office and resources as an MP to benefit company G8wayInternational, and misused his role as an MP to advance his own financial interest. The ICAC has made 18 recommendations relating to MP codes of conduct, training for parliamentarians and staff, and improving the integrity of government grant schemes.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ICAC recommends Daryl Maguire be referred to the DPP

children.content: While ICAC will not be obtaining advice of the DPP over the possible prosecution of Ms Berejiklian,
it will be referring Mr Maguire to the DPP for possible criminal charges
over his involvement in an alleged visa scheme involving company G8wayInternational.
The ICAC found Mr Maguire improperly used his office and resources as an MP to benefit company G8wayInternational, and misused his role as an MP to advance his own financial interest.
The ICAC has made
18 recommendations relating to MP codes of conduct,
training for parliamentarians and staff, and improving the integrity of government grant schemes.

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX makes early gains

children.content: The ASX 200 dipped a tiny bit on the opening bell, but it quickly jumped up a bit.
After 30-mins of trade it's up 23 points (0.33%).
The top five movers:
Paladin Energy: +5%, to $0.73
Domain Holdings Australia: +3.68%, to $3.66
West African Resources: +2.99%, to $0.86
Sayona Mining: +2.94%, to $0.175
REA Group: +2.55%, to $141.12
Bottom five movers:

Pilbara Minerals: -2.48%, to $4.71
Ramsay Health Care: -2.62%, to $55,79
Collins Foods: -2.31%, to $9.71

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Commodities analysts in the research team at Commonwealth Bank have put out an interesting note this morning on industrial profits in China. They say base metal and iron ore prices finished mostly lower overnight on demand concerns in China. Industrial profits in China fell by 12.6%/yr in May, confirming fears that China’s commodity intensive economy is still facing headwinds. They say the fall in industrial profits over January to May (-18.8%/yr) is rivalling the decline experienced in 2020 over the same period (-19.3%/yr). They've produced this graph to show what they mean: They say the 2020 numbers were adversely impacted by China’s nationwide COVID-19 lockdowns, so the fact that the first five months of 2023 and 2020 are showing comparable declines in industrial profits show the beleaguered state of China’s commodity-intensive economy right now.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Base metals and iron ore fall on weak industrial profits in China

children.content: Commodities analysts in the research team at Commonwealth Bank have put out an interesting note this morning on industrial profits in China.
They say base metal and iron ore prices finished mostly lower overnight on demand concerns in China.
Industrial profits in China fell by 12.6%/yr in May, confirming fears that China’s commodity intensive economy is still facing headwinds.
They say the fall in industrial profits over January to May (-18.8%/yr) is rivalling the decline experienced in 2020 over the same period (-19.3%/yr).
They've produced this graph to show what they mean:

They say the 2020 numbers were adversely impacted by China’s nationwide COVID-19 lockdowns, so the fact that the first five months of 2023 and 2020 are showing comparable declines in industrial profits show the beleaguered state of China’s commodity-intensive economy right now.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reuters has a piece this morning marking a potential record for Apple's market capitalisation. It says Apple stock climbed to a record high close on Wednesday and was on the cusp of a $3 trillion market capitalisation today. Apple has yet to end a trading session with a stock market value above $3 trillion. It briefly peaked above $3 trillion in intra-day trading on Jan. 3, 2022 before closing the session just below that mark. The latest gains in shares of the world's most valuable company follow strong rebounds this year from several of Wall Street's technology-related heavyweights, fueled by bets that the Federal Reserve is nearing the end of its campaign of U.S. interest rate hikes, and by optimism about the potential for artificial intelligence. "There hasn't really been any new information fundamentally that would be supportive of the stock move," said Thomas Martin, Senior Portfolio Manager at Globalt Investments. "What you're left with is, you know, the market itself."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Apple stock hits record, on cusp of $3 trillion market value

children.content: Reuters has a piece this morning marking a potential record for Apple's market capitalisation.
It says Apple stock climbed to a record high close on Wednesday and was on the cusp of a $3 trillion market capitalisation today.

Apple has yet to end a trading session with a stock market value above $3 trillion. It briefly peaked above $3 trillion in intra-day trading on Jan. 3, 2022 before closing the session just below that mark.

The latest gains in shares of the world's most valuable company follow strong rebounds this year from several of Wall Street's technology-related heavyweights, fueled by bets that the Federal Reserve is nearing the end of its campaign of U.S. interest rate hikes, and by optimism about the potential for artificial intelligence.

"There hasn't really been any new information fundamentally that would be supportive of the stock move," said Thomas Martin, Senior Portfolio Manager at Globalt Investments. "What you're left with is, you know, the market itself."
